posts.name: Will Benjes|1710|2024 Chief Operations Officer
posts.cooked:
As our team, Team 1710, was disassembling the robot tonight we noticed a significant change in wear between one of our colson wheels compared to the other three. This being a new wheel type we are testing, we are interested in hearing if other teams are having the same issue as well as the causes for this problem. 20231107_193526 1920×2560 410 KB

20231107_193526 1920×2560 410 KB

20231107_193526 1920×2560 410 KB

posts.name: SndMndBdy
posts.cooked:
Is that picture as extreme as it seems, or is that an optical illusion?  Can you provide the measurements of the wheels?

Is there an extreme weight imbalance on your robot?

posts.name: Will Benjes|1710|2024 Chief Operations Officer
posts.cooked: It is about as bad as it seems in the picture. The left was 3.875 and right was 3.5. Our robot center of mass is even as well.

posts.name: Jon K.
posts.cooked: I wonder if you had an issue at some point where one wheel just spun for a while. While at an off season recently, a robot lost CAN for 3 of 4 pods, and spun a wheel so much they ended up melting the carpet to their wheel. That seems like there was something else going on here, if your CoM is as even as you say.

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked:
I wonder if the wear pattern 2767 found in 2017/2018 was actually this, but mitigated by the dually swerve.

Considering 3538 broke the match record yet again on colsons (I believe anyway) it would be interesting to hear what they have to say on the matter.

In this case it almost looks like this wheel was fighting the rest of the drivetrain for a prolonged period. Like it was zeroed wrong and ran for a while. Failing that, is there an auto routine or more likely a certain maneuver (I e. Turning clockwise while accelerating out of the feeder station) that was placing high load on one corner of the bot? Short instances of abnormally high load could conceivably cause temps to spike or something.

posts.name: Cory Walters
posts.cooked: We saw the colsons all worn down evenly on 4 modules though. This is some thing different.

posts.name: SndMndBdy
posts.cooked:
By the end of the tournament, can you describe how the robot was sitting on the wheels?  I can see two possible options:

-The small wheel was barely touching the carpet, and the other three wheels were firmly on the ground

-The whole robot had tilted down towards the small wheel and the wheel diagonally opposite it was up in the air.

I can imagine either of these scenarios leading to a “runaway” type of problem.  Imagine that for whatever innocuous reason, that one wheel initially wore down just a tiny bit more than the others.  Then maybe one of two things starts happening:

-If it is the former of the above, then perhaps that wheel got in a situation where it is making less traction with the carpet, and starts spinning at its free speed.  The light touch with the carpet creates a situation where the wheel is acting like a grindstone.  This causes it to shrink just a tiny bit more, which exacerbates the problem.  This process continues to get worse until the wheel has shrunk so much that is completely not in contact with the ground.

-If it is the latter of the above, then perhaps once that wheel shrunk just a a bit, the robot leaned down it more if there was a slight imbalance in that direction.   This extra weight caused it to wear a little bit faster, which then exacerbated the problem. And so on and so forth.

posts.name: Fritz G
posts.cooked: Thanks for sharing this! Did you start to notice any strange behavior during matches that would be explained by the difference in wheel diameter?

posts.name: marshall
posts.cooked:
Is there a chance you’ve got different gear ratios on the different modules?

Is there anything in your code that would cause that one wheel to drive faster than the others?

posts.name: Brad
posts.cooked: When I hear uneven tire wear I think alignment.  Is there any chance the wheel was slightly misaligned with the other wheels, or possibly during Cowtown did your frame get bent.

posts.name: Allison K
posts.cooked:
Perplexing.  We’ve run Colsons on SDS modules for ~20 events now (the comp robot, plus a handful of events worth of practice/offseason robots) and we have seen wear, but not uneven wear like this.  The most worn down set of wheels we have played 5 events (and practice in between) and was ~3.5" when we finally swapped them, but the wear was even.

Are the fork assemblies on the worn one tightened down?  We had a set of forks so loose one of the mounting screws was just no longer installed at all.  I didn’t pay attention to how the wheel in that module was but I can see that situation leading to some wonky wear.

Other stuff we have seen:

Chunks taken out of a wheel: We were using a piece of 1x1 on the ground to represent the barrier wall and kept smacking the end of it

Carpet melted onto wheel (twice): Various code deploy and CAN mishaps that resulted in one wheel spinning in place (oops)

A flatish spot on a wheel: From dragging one module for multiple matches (also oops)

posts.name: Joshua
posts.cooked: At our offseason event, Cowtown Throwdown, we didn’t seem to have many issues with a misaligned wheel, and as we set up the robot on the field, I don’t remember noticing a wheel shaved down that much. All of them seemed fine. After the event, we had an open house, where they said they noticed some drift, however, it didn’t seem significant enough to cause this much wear. We only noticed this last night when we took the robot apart, and we have no idea when this actually happened. In terms of our robot, the frame seems just fine, and our weight is properly balanced, with the center of mass being extremely low and towards the middle of the robot. We’re hoping that it’s just a misalignment issue, as the other two wheels are exactly the same as the wheel on the left. The main issue we had during playoffs at cowtown was power draw issues, with the robot barely making it to the end of the match, which was extremely abnormal. There may be a possible correlation between those issues and this wheel, as the module was fighting the other three.

posts.name: Nyx
posts.cooked: Motor wired backwards? That’s never a good thing, although I’d’ve expected a motor to smoke, but you’re probly using BLDC and a gearbox that makes it easier for the wheel to spin so smoking is less likely maybe. I’m just rambling though.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Everything and nothing, all at the same time

posts.custom_user_title: Everything and nothing, all at the same time

posts.name: Joshua
posts.cooked: Knowing that your team ran Colson’s all season and for a total of 20 events (congrats!), how much did tread wear affect driving during tele-op and especially autos? Were AprilTags essential to making sure auto routines worked? How often did you swap wheels?

posts.name: Allison K
posts.cooked:
Driving during teleop was not affected by wheel wear at all as far as we could tell.  In that regard we like the colsons much better than tread (which we ran for ~3 offseason events while we were initially learning to swerve) because the surface and handling of the colsons is consistent throughout the life of the wheel, vs. tread where it is high traction when new and then degrades and changes the handling characteristics over the life of the tread.  Theoretically handling differences due to tread wear could be addressed by swapping tread very frequently, but I’m not about that life.

We used both odometry and April Tags and saw no difference in the performance of our autos with new vs. worn wheels.  I don’t have any more scientific or concrete information to relay than that, as autos are a complex enough system that it’s hard to single out a specific factor.  We are still developing our expertise in our swerve code base and I think that mattered more for our autos than anything having to do with our wheels did.

Wheel swaps on the comp robot:

2 events (Milford/ Muskegon)

2 events (Troy 2/ MSC)

2 events (Worlds/ Big Bang)

5 Events (IRI/ MROC/ MARC/ Goonettes/ Kettering)

3 Events (Chezy/ WMRI/ Bot Bash)

1 event (STEMley)

(I think, my memory is a bit faulty)

In all cases the wheels also lived through practice between the events listed. We could have run three districts in season just fine and swapped for MSC/Worlds, but at the time we didn’t have the experience we do now and didn’t want to risk anything new or unexpected happening at MSC. The first set from the comp robot was reallocated to practice robot with the intent to see how long we could run them before they were ruined, however I lost track of if we actually left that set on that robot or not.  I’ll have to check.  We do have one set of used wheels that’s very visibly abused but that might be the set that ran 5 events + practice and day camp in between.

We have done individual wheels swaps as well, in cases where we ruined just one wheel (flat spots, melted carpet), and the slight difference between the new wheel and the others didn’t seem to matter.  Initial wheel wear is more rapid, I think we went from 4" to 3.83" in one event, but after that we were losing around .05" per event.

posts.name: Brendan Manning
posts.cooked:
Allison_K:

We do have one set of used wheels that’s very visibly abused

Any chance you can post pictures of these?

posts.name: Cory Walters
posts.cooked:
I am trying to find a picture of it, but because it was a dually Colson wheel set up. The outer edges of the wheels would wear faster then the inside edge causing a trapezoid look to them. This was seen on all the wheels so it was not a Colson specific reason.

What you are describing sounds like you have something wrong on that corner of the swerve drive.

Here is a cad shot of an old module for reference.

link_counts.title: Looking for Info on 2767 Stryke Force Swerve

posts.name: Dan_Karol
posts.cooked:
Chaos 131 had a swerve encoder issue on one module at the last event.  We knew about it but drove anyway.  It resulted in one wheel being initialized at a slightly arbitrary angle (usually within 45 degrees of the true angle).  If the angle was within 20deg we didn’t even really notice the issue during the match for the most part.  What this misalignment did was cause our robot to bald that wheel before the others.

From our experience, I’m guessing the calibration on that wheel is imprecise and resulting in this wheel having scrub when you are driving in normal conditions.
